newsitem.title: USA: China bans U.S. poultry imports from 10 states.
newsitem.headline: China bans U.S. poultry imports from 10 states.

text.p: China has banned imports of poultry from 10 U.S. states because of fears the birds carry a fowl plague, the U.S. Agriculture Department said Wednesday.
The ban threatens an export market worth about $500 million a year.
"Effective yesterday, China has banned imports of live poultry and poultry meat from 10 states," said John Reddington, director of the department's Dairy, Livestock and Poultry division.
The states affected are Arkansas, Florida, Maryland, Minnesota, New Jersey, New York, North Carolina, Texas, Utah and Wisconsin.
Chinese authorities had voiced fears the poultry products carried a virus called highly pathogenic avian influenza, or HPAI.
Reddington said the department was sending a technical team to Beijing to try to clear up apparent confusion on the part of China over the difference between HPAI and avian influenza, or AI.
"We believe there's some confusion by the Chinese over the type of avian influenza that China has allegedly discovered," Reddington said.
Reddington said there had been no cases of HPAI in the United States since the early 1980s.
A U.S. quarantine official based in China told Reuters last week that the virus could not be transmitted to people who ate the meat of infected birds.
China is the second-biggest market in the world, after Russia, for U.S. poultry products. It is the only market for U.S. chicken feet.
U.S. poultry exports to China in 1995 totalled 330,000 tons transshipped through Hong Kong alone, worth $445 million, according to the U.S. Poultry and Egg Export Council.
Every day thirty 23-ton containers of U.S. chicken feet crossed the border from Hong Kong into China, according to the council's spokeswoman, Sarah Li.
An official at the U.S. embassy in Beijing said the AI virus was common worldwide, particularly in wild fowl, but was not present in commercial poultry flocks in the United States.
Another U.S. official said the AI virus may have been detected in ostriches imported from the United States as breeding stock on Chinese ostrich farms.
"Ostrich raising in China has become very popular and a lot of the breeding stock is brought in from the U.S.," the marketing official said.
Officials of China's Administration of Animal and Plant Quarantine and the U.S. Embassy in Beijing met Tuesday in an effort to resolve the issue, the embassy official said.
"It was a frank, candid and open meeting -- they listened to us and agreed that we should talk more about it, which we will as soon as possible," the official said.
